page.content:
Writing and speaking to our experiences optimizes relevance, value, and authenticity. After drawing inspiration about storytelling from The Moth and practicing speaking skills by creating a TED Talk, you can have learners utilize a speech-to-text (STT) tool to tell their own story. After capturing their story with STT, have learners share it with a peer. The peer can practice reading it or use a supportive technology like text-to-speech. The final step is to have learners write (by hand or type) their own story.  

Here are some Writing Prompts to Guide Writing YOUR STORY:

  • Autobiography: Introduce us to who you are. Share your hobbies, interests, family background, and anything else you want others to know about the real you.
  • Holiday: Share what you did on a recent holiday or vacation. Include photos or videos.
  • Best memory: What is a memory you will never forget? 
  • Funniest moment: Tell us about a time you couldn't stop laughing. 
  • Hardest challenge you overcame: What made it so hard? 
  • Hero/Mentor: What is it about this person that makes them so special?

Go back to the Try It Yourself Section for a list of all Try it Yourself Options.
